subject: Re: [junit] Cactus vs JUnit
msgSnippet: ... Cactus is good for testing EJBs inside the real container. To use JUnit, you need to separate the EJB into two parts: the plain Java part, and the part
messageBody:
grprabhavathi wrote:
> Hi all,
> I have joined this group newly.
> We are doing a J2ee project.
> I would like to know whether to use JUnit separately for testing EJB
> and other Java classes or go for Cactus framework for performing
> these unit tests.

Cactus is good for testing EJBs inside the real container. To use JUnit,
you need to separate the EJB into two parts: the plain Java part, and
the part that integrates with the EJB framework. See _JUnit Recipes_,
chapter 11 for details.

> Another question is with respect to UI testing.
> We found that Httpunit consumes lot of effort in writing the black
> box tests for testing UI.

What are three ways in which using HttpUnit consumes so much effort?

> We also foundthat Cactus is not that useful for testing UI as it
> cannot do the navigational testing, i.e. navigating from one screen
> to another.

I find this surprising. If Vince Massol can read this, would you care to
comment?

I have used HtmlUnit to test the user interface, but I have to tell you
that when I test a user interface, I test /only/ the user interface, and
not the entire application from end to end. You might be doing something
different. I find that testing the entire application from end to end
/and/ trying to do exhaustive boundary checking is a formula for
disaster, so I use other techniques. Once again, see _JUnit Recipes_,
chapters 12 and 13 for details.

Best of luck.
